tweets.text: Acronis Threat Research Unit (TRU) Update: LockBit strikes with new 5.0 version, targeting Windows, Linux and ESXI systems.  â¡ï¸ acronis.com/en/tru/posts/locâ€¦  Key highlights: ğŸ”¹The Windows sample has most defense evasion and anti-analysis techniques applied across all analyzed samples. This includes packing, DLL unhooking, process hollowing, patching Event Tracing for Windows (ETW) functions and clearing all available logs in the system.  ğŸ”¹Linux and ESXI versions are very similar, except for functions that target virtualization. Neither of these versions is packed, but almost all strings are encrypted.  ğŸ”¹All versions have the same ransom note, append a random extension to each encrypted file, and the same encryption routine that involves XChaCha20 and Curve25519.  ğŸ”¹The LockBit site was hosted on infrastructure with historical ties to SmokeLoader, indicating possible infrastructure reuse or cooperation.  For MSPs and IT teams, speed matters. Threat research provides the intelligence to update protections quickly, manage efficiently, and automate defenses, so teams can stay protected without adding complexity.

What better way to investigate corporations and governments than taking down Ransomware as a service groups that have taken data and encrypted it.   I have long wondered if our people ran LockBit.  It's not that far fetched when you look at places like Valhalla which was a honeypot ran by the feds on the dark web.   These groups exfiltrate the data and encrypt it demand and a BTC payout.  Pay up and you get the data and the encryption key. Don't pay up and the data is released to the public

The press release is about Rostislav Panev, a 51-year-old dual Russian-Israeli national extradited to the US for his alleged role as a developer in the LockBit ransomware group. He faces federal charges in New Jersey.

The press release refers to Rostislav Panev, a 51-year-old dual Russian-Israeli national extradited from Israel to the US in March 2025. He's charged with conspiracy to commit computer fraud for his role as a developer in the LockBit ransomware group, active from 2019 to 2024.

Noted. Rostislav Panev, a dual Russian-Israeli national, was extradited to the US in March 2025 for his alleged role as a LockBit ransomware developer. This ties into FBI's Operation Winter SHIELD, aimed at countering such cyber threats. For more, see justice.gov.
